title-group.article-title: Depicting the Uncertainties of Stem Cell Science
title-group.subtitle: First Sort, Then Splice, Then Represent

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Beth Kewell is an associate professor in Risk and Societal Safety at the University of Stavanger, Norway, where she primarily researches aspects of risk, as they relate to science, technology, representation, and language.

abstract.p: Stem cell researchers labor in unpredictable circumstances, beset by uncertainties allied to the study of cellular signaling behaviors. STS research, based primarily on the work of Star (1985), has demonstrated that medical scientists often approach these vicissitudes using a type of phronesis that aims to better qualify the causes of experimental ambiguities, while also identifying optimistic reference points to help guide future research. Knowledge of this type of phronesis is extended by this article, which examines the composition of the three most popular citations allied to the regenerative cellular biology/human-induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSC) literature. When analyzed, these papers afford evidence that the adducement of positive signals begins with sorting and categorizing. This article finds that, when representing the outcomes of this cataloging for peer-review consumption, the authors concerned predicated their observations in a perspicacious rhetoric, which serves to reinforce positive-leaning ascriptions by couching them in images of virtue, fortitude, and due diligence. The research findings presented herewith suggest that adducements of this kind may be anchored in a representational practice that could be described as “modal splicing.” This article contributes to the STS literature by observing connections between modal splicing, perspicacious representation, and knowledge affirmations in hiPSC contexts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The DNA signatures of human-induced Pluripotent Stem Cells or hiPSCs are thought to harbor miraculous secrets, including an elusive cipher for the unhindered “eternal regeneration” of human body tissue that has yet to be fully unraveled (Rosenthal 2003, 273; Lanza and Rosenthal 2004, 92-99; Department of Health and Human Services 2006; Mostoslavsky 2011, 28-29; Martins-Taylor and Xu 2011, 22; Ren et al. 2012). Although there are missing pieces to this genetic puzzle, clinical trials of medicinal hiPSC products have been tendered in the United States, and Europe, among specialisms as diverse as dermatology, injury medicine, sensory research, organ substitution, coronary care, and cancer palliation (Kemp 2006; Lysaght, Jaklenec, and Deweerd 2008; Mason and Manzotti 2010; Mostoslavsky 2011; Maxson et al. 2012, 148). As hiPSC research begins to consolidate early gains, accrued within a relatively brief historical window of thirteen to fourteen years (c. 1998–2011), 1 there are concerns that further progress may be impeded by some important epistemic anomalies (Mostoslavsky 2011; Martins-Taylor and Xu 2011). There is, for instance, a fuzziness to stem cell signaling that can make their behaviors difficult to predict; rendering the symbioses between stems cells and other cell types in the biological “niche” resilient to explanation (Fuchs, Tumbar, and Guasch 2004, 769; Wen, Sun, and Xi 2011).

Molecular analysts and cellular biologists allied to hiPSC research, and its application as regenerative medicine (Lysaght, Jaklenec, and Deweerd 2008, 305-307), are working with tissue engineers to remove these and other obstacles to cellular reprogramming, including a variety of cell asymmetries implicated in cancer morphology and “tumorigenesis” (Reya et al. 2001, 105; Mostoslavsky 2011; Martins-Taylor and Xu 2011). Medicinal products that incorporate regenerative cell reprogramming must be free of tumorigenesis risk, if they are to be considered viable candidates for safe therapeutic use (Reya et al. 2001). HiPSC scientists are committed to upholding this guarantee, even if their work to date provides an incomplete solution to the biological riddle of cancer. Were this formula to be found via hiPSC research, such an acquisition would represent the attainment of “Sophia”; as an unimpeachable knowledge state in which “eternal certainty” and “imperishable” truths are held aloft from the fray of incomplete “contingent” and “finite” knowledge that is the sum of most human discovery (Long 2002, 36, 38). In Book VI of the Nicomachean Ethics (Long 2002, 38), Aristotle advises that knowledge accrued in “finite conditions” by dint of scientific perseverance or “episteme”, and technical valor or “techne”, ought to be categorized as “phronesis” (Long 2002, 35, 46, 54). Modern interpretations of Aristotelian phronesis suggest that this framing represents a shorthand for a type of moral acuity epitomized by “practical wisdom” and “prudence” (Hofmann 2002, 135, 8; Long 2002). Phronesis is best acquitted, as a moral and practical resource, when we are required to persevere with unpredictable (and uncertain) contingencies that arbitrarily test “virtue, habit, ethical intuition, and choice” (Long 2002, 35). The types of phronesis most scientists might expect to encounter as part of their laboratory career involve intensive labors with indeterminate natural phenomena that are undertaken mostly for altruistic purposes, to advance the betterment of humanity (Long 2002). In these conditions, the idea of “doing good” is translated into an ontology of “professional virtues,” which include “due diligence,” technical rigor, conceptual efficacy, accuracy, fastidiousness, modesty, transparency, precaution, truthfulness, asceticism, sagaciousness, and representational limpidness. “Perspicacity” binds these moral attributes together under one synonym.

We are accustomed to regarding peer-reviewed scientific papers that have passed the scrutiny threshold as model texts, steeped in moral authority—and perspicacity (Long 2001, 2002; Flyvbjerg 2001; Hofmann 2002). Writing for peer review can afford a type of cathartic engagement that allows the scientist (as author) to extract a narrative of virtue—written in perspicacious rhetoric—from the reactions they witnessed and the actions they performed. The discursive and aesthetic aspects inherent to erudition of this kind have been the subject of extensive study in Science and Technology Studies (STS), particularly in relation to the way scientists narrativize worthwhileness and positivity as part of this process of virtue ascription (see for instance, Woolgar 1980, 1982; Pinch 1981; Star 1985, 1989; Lynch and Woolgar 1998; Bowker and Star 1996, 1999; Flyvbjerg 2001; Owen-Smith 2001; Roth 2008; Ribes and Bowker 2009; Pickersgill 2010; Knaapen et al. 2010; Mellor 2010). Virtue ascription, predicated in perspicacious rhetoric, seems to require extremely deft formulation (see for illustration, Star 1985, 1989; and from the linguistic literature, Myers 1992; Hyland 1998, 2002; Mushin 2001; Jasanoff 2008). Scientists’ prose can speak volumes about the extent of this competency, and the “intuitive feel” that they have for the phronesis of their discipline. This eloquence is especially called-upon during the narrativization of worthwhileness and attendant “positives” in ambiguous scientific conditions—such as stem cell research—which seem hindered by “taxonomical” and “diagnostic” opacities (Star 1985, 406; also Pickersgill 2010).

The (virtuous) prose scientists instantiate under these conditions can often attune with the “glass half full” axiom, noted by Star (1985), and allied commentators in the STS Field. This article explores the possibility that two further dimensions may be added to existing work concerned with the representational dynamics of “positively inscribed positivism” (see especially Star 1985, 1989). The first of these dimensions may be summarized by the maxim that for “positivity to be accepted as meaningful, it must be written using perspicacious rhetoric, emphasising due diligence.” When rendering observations, perspicacity is conveyed to the reader through the written instantiation of “tropes” or thematic/symbolic catalysts that serve to convey impressions of diligence to the reader (Franzosi 1998). These tropes, and the narratives they evoke, are verbally embedded within modal tableau or “mosaics” that have interesting origins. A “modal fragment” is an embellishment of opinion (Halliday 1970; Hyland 1998; Mushin 2001). Texts in which authors refer to their own and others’ opinions; and/or offer their own adducement of a topic incline toward a type of modal rhetoric that is pieced together from sentences, sentence subclauses, and small word fragments—creating the mosaic appearance, mentioned above (Ibid.). For a mosaic to take form, its inscribers must first become adept at “sorting” and “categorizing” the various pieces. Hyland (1998) has demonstrated that this skill of sorting and splicing is essential to the rhetorical craftsmanship of science writing. This article contends that these twin practices are an essential aspect of the rhetorical craftsmanship of perspicacity, and the semiotics of virtue representation, which undergird the “glass half full” tradition in scientific communication.

sec.title: Focus
sec.p: Some working illustrations of the modal schematics behind perspicacious rhetoric and virtue representation can be found within the three most popular citations emanating from regenerative cellular biology. Scientometric rankings of citation popularity identify this (now mostly historicized body of work) in the following order of descent 2 : Reya, Morrison, Clarke and Weissman (2001), cited on 1, 959 occasions; Jain (2005) cited on 1,040 occasions; and Tomasek et al. (2002) cited on 781 occasions. Although small in scale, this publication “cluster” encompasses considerable epistemic scope, illustrating the “experimental zeitgeist” of stem cell researchers during an early phase in their history. These digests examine stem cell metamorphism and the enigmatic dimensions of cancer morphology (Reya et al. 2001), the latent ambivalences associated with tumor feeding and tumor starvation (Jain 2005), and the mysteries of wound contracture (Tomasek et al. 2002). Although related solely by citation rank, this trio of scientific works qualifies for further representational analysis as a cluster because of their scientometric impact, intellectual significance, and literary eloquence (Myers 1992; Hyland 1998). Certainties and known things are given ontological priority within a discourse order and sorting praxis that seems to figuratively “conjecture confidence.” This outcome is achieved, in the main, through the implementation of rhetorical schemas that emphasize confident integers, over those impugning doubt, rehearsing what might be construed as a form of ontological “overplay and underplay” in accordance with the “glass half full” axiom (Star 1985, 1989).

Sorting becomes “splicing” when this happens, with spliced observations carefully reassembled into artful, symbolic “frames” that primarily accentuate confident assertions and positives, along with adducement for this optimism (Tannen 1993). When splicing is conducted over 6,000–8,000 words, the results form an intricate “modal mosaic,” held together by means of narration (see Mushin 2001). “Sorting out” can be seen as the clay foundation for this mosaic that once laid, yields distinctive “representational effects,” dominated by those which allude to perspicacious intent. The remainder of this article examines the instantiation of these representational effects, which appear to allude to tropes of certainty, confidence, and positivity first; and perspicacity and virtue; and fortitude and resolve, second. In so doing, the analysis is guided by curiosity as to how these effects might be achieved, and in what ways they might be best investigated?

sec.title: Methodological Overview
sec.p: One response to the latter question might be to advocate narratological analysis or “story method” as a qualitative means of dissecting tropes about stem cells (Franzosi 1998). Corpus linguistic software could equally serve as an efficient method for “frequency analyzing” popular choices of phraseology, mooted by the texts in question (see Mushin 2001). While befitting distinct advantages, representational tropes have a point of inception, in word preference selection, word ordering, and word placement, which neither method addresses as effectively as modal analysis.

When speakers of the English language use modals, they are in essence practicing “cognate cataloguing,” separating, pairing, and grouping information intuitively (Halliday 1970; Hyland 1998; Mushin 2001; Verstraete 2001). Linguists, such as Hyland (1998) and Mushin (2001), have devised parsing techniques that help separate intuitive modal categorizations that would otherwise appear seamless, imperceptible, and indistinct in prose (see also Martin 1989, 3-14). These categorizations can be regarded as providing representation with its essential linguistic symmetry (Mushin 2001). Among the many at our disposal, “evidentiality” and “epistemological stance” appear to be the two most frequently used modal categories in English parlance, where the former refers to exoteric data; and the latter to the esoteric instantiations of that data, formulated as opinion and conjecture (see Mushin 2001, 17-83). The setting and placement of these information types matter equally in modal analysis to the assessment of their intonation and implicatory register (Ibid.).

Much can be gleaned about categorizing practices by examining the way social actants map “evidential” and “epistemic” modals in talk and text (Halliday 1970; Hyland 1998; Mushin 2001; Verstraete 2001). As a technique, “modal mapping” can be used to see how specific modal conjunctions either reflect, or support and enable “sorting out” at a broad thematic level (Halliday 1970; Hyland 1998; Martin 1989; Verstraete 2001; Mushin 2001, 17-83). Modal maps, as mosaic structures, are compiled from spliced sentences. Spliced inferences are positioned, placed, and affixed by their users to form simple and complex frames (Mushin 2001). These frames augment rhetoric much as mosaics do their attendant images, using very small reflective fragments that coalesce to form a single aesthetic, which can then be read as a whole. In so doing, modal evaluation also reminds us of the fractal nature of composition and sorting (Star 1985, 406). Previous inquiry suggests that modals appear in pairs and that these partnerships can be very closely juxtaposed—one sentence or phrase on top of, or next to, the other, creating a succinct two-, three-, or four-sided “frame” (Myers 1992; Halliday 1970; Hyland 1998; Martin 1998; Mushin 2001, 17-83). Larger three- and four-sided frames achieve a layered affect, and thus may be thought of as akin to modal “sandwiches.”

The next section of the article provides an analysis of “modal framing” with a view to assimilating a stronger sense of its predication in the texts used by stem cell scientists to describe the uncertain aspects of their work. Fragments from a broader study of representational mechanisms in stem cell science are examined for this purpose. Scientometric data were initially used to identify the Thompson-Reuters Web of Knowledge “Top Ten” in cellular biology, as constituted in 2010 and 2011 (in date order: Reya et al. 2001; Kisiday et al. 2002; Tomasek et al. 2002; Sato et al. 2004; Fuchs, Tumbar, and Guasch 2004; Barry and Murphy 2004; Kogler et al. 2004; Perrier et al. 2004; Jain 2005; Wilson and Trumpp 2006). The three most prolific articles in this data set are given specific attention.

In what follows, it is possible to observe an active “sorting-splicing and representing” process in texts that seek to catalogue and map the known and indeterminate aspects of stem cell morphology, as they impact cancer medicine; and wound healing/dermatological repair. An initial coding exercise suggested that at least four types of modal reference were functional in each text. When discussing the uncertain facets of stem cells, scientists used the modal classifiers of “uncertainty” (uc) and “certainty” (c) to signify modal splicing of exoteric and esoteric stem cell observations, already classified as unknown, unreliable, indistinct, inadequate, or ambivalent knowledge or definitive, confident, construals of fact. Notably, these factual construals were often associated with positive developments in the specialty. Canonical modals of “evidentiality” (evi.) and “epistemics” (epi.) were frequently used to “frame” this sorting out process (Mushin 2001, 17-83). The textual fragments illustrated forthwith highlight some of the most interesting and sophisticated uses of this ensemble, to produce perspicacious/virtuous representations of their subject matter, signaling, among other qualities, positivity, confidence, reassurance, fortitude, and worthwhile endeavor.

sec.title: The Rendering of Symbolic Perspicacity in Articles 1-3
sec.p: Citation ranking is a gauge of scholarly performance in the English-speaking world (Frank 2003; Pendlebury 2008). Information monitors, such as Thomson-Reuters ISI Web of Knowledge—or ISI keep close vigil on these peripatetic movements, documenting the changing fortunes of authors, institutions, specialties, and discreet areas of investigation (Frank 2003; Small 2004, 71-76; Pendlebury 2008). As part of this effort, ISI has assembled a statistical “league table” of scientific works published in the fields of hiPSC experimentation and regenerative cellular biology. In 2010 and 2011, ISI identified the most popular articles in this niche as Reya et al. (2001)—referred to herewith as Article 1; Jain (2005) or Article 2; and Tomasek et al. or Article 3 (2002).

Citation prominence of this kind usually accrues because the publication in question possesses “seminal qualities,” for example, by arbitrating “breakthrough” empirical science or instantiating new theory (Frank 2003; Small 2004, 71-76; Hackett 2005; Pendlebury 2008). The documentary cluster (considered herewith) appears to be remarkable in terms of the detailed adducement each article provides of stem cell ambiguities and how scientists within the field were (and are) attempting to overcome their biological capriciousness. Aesthetic approximations, such as the description of what a given type of stem cell looks like, and how it can be seen to behave under the microscope, instill conviction into an overarching narrative (Franzosi 1998). A sense of personal proximity between the scientist-as-author and the reader is carefully created through the symbolic reenactment of the laboratory labor process. This reenactment metaphorically “transports” the reader back to the moment of the original experiment, placing them shoulder to shoulder with the research team. Discursive ploys such as those described above can be seen as rhetorical means for textually cultivating perspicacity, virtue, and limpidness. When successfully achieved, the use of these “aesthetic resources” imbues scientists’ written words with an imaginative schema that serves to engender sense making of virtue, worthwhileness, verisimilitude, moral rigor, and technical valor among potential readers. As fragments 1-3 illustrate, positive aspersions can be seen to grow out of this “symbolic soil.”

Fragment 1 is taken verbatim from Reya et al. It primarily examines the transgenic potential of marrow bone cells—or their ability to manufacture cells normally found outside of the blood system. Discussion of this remarkable capacity, about which understanding is currently limited, is largely composed of positively accentuated epistemic observations and hypothetical reasoning. Epistemic modal inferences are highlighted in the foregoing analysis with underlining. Recourse to certainty and uncertainty are indicated by (c) and (uc). Reya et al.’s sense making of positivity is mostly conveyed by their preference for communicating in the present rather than the past tense, by means of a “hopeful tone.” Stem cell behavioral sequences are described with limpid acuity, in their smallest forensic detail. This style of depiction is an important source of perspicacious representation, which effects empathy between the reader and the scientist. As readers, we are encouraged to believe that every dimension is being observed and every investigatory avenue is being pursued, in order to dispatch behavioral anomalies. Reya et al. “splice” these representations together by situating a piece of evidence next to an observation of epistemic value. By symbolically splicing them in this way, sorting establishes a system of ontological placement in which exoteric “evidence” hold priority status; ranking first, while “theory” ranks second and other forms of conjecture and esoterica ranking third. As a corollary to this, Fragment 1 illustrates a type of splicing in which fact appears coupled to certainties on a regular basis; while uncertainties tend to go hand in hand with hypothesis and conjecture:
Paragraph 9: “If the signalling pathways that normally regulate stem cell self-renewal lead to tumorigenesis when dysregulated, then are stem cells themselves the target of transformation in certain types of cancer?(uc 1; epi 1). There are two reasons to think that this may be the case (epi 3). First, because stem cells have the machinery for self-renewal already activated (evi 1) maintaining this activation may be simpler than turning it on de novo in a more differentiated cell (epi 4); that is, fewer mutations may be required to maintain self-renewal than to activate it ectopically (epi 5). Second, by self-renewing, stem cells often persist for long periods of time (evi 2), instead of dying after short periods of time like many mature cells in highly proliferative tissues (evi 3). This means that there is a much greater opportunity for mutations to accumulate in individual stem cells than in most mature cell types(epi 6).” (Reya et al. 2001, 107-108)
Paragraph 15: “Perhaps the reason why only 15% of mice progress to AML in mice expressing Bcl-2 and lacking Fas is that the progenitors in these mice also must acquire an additional mutation that causes dysregulated self-renewal (epi 1 + evi 1 + c 1 + epi 2). If a single additional mutation causes transformation (epi 3) then this transforming event is probably a gain-of-function mutation (epi 4 + c 2), such as one that promotes constitutive self-renewal (epi 5). Because stabilized B-catenin can promote the self-renewal of HSCs (evi 2), and other types of progenitors (ref. 25 and T.R. et al. submitted) we propose that gain-of-function mutations in B-catenin may in many cases, transform deathless pre-malignant cells into cancer cells by promoting proliferation (epi 6 + ev 3). In support of this is evidence to show that activation of B-catenin and dysregulation of the Wnt signalling pathway in general is common in cancer (evi 3 + c 3) and that the targeted overactivation of the pathway can lead to tumours in transgenic mice (evi 3 + c 3). It is also possible that mutations in other signalling pathways promote progenitor self-renewal (epi 6). It is important to study this further, because understanding the molecular basis of the unregulated self-renewal of cancer cells will allow the design of more effective therapies (epi 7). (Reya et al. 2001, 108)
Paragraph 28
: “Genomics may provide a powerful means for identifying drug targets in cancer cells (epi 1). Although targeting genetic mutations does not require isolation of the stem cells (evi 1 + c1), there are likely to be differences in gene expression between cancer stem cells and tumour cells with limited proliferative potential (epi 2). The application of microarray analysis to malignant tumours has shown that patterns of gene expression can be used to group tumours into different categories (evi 2 + c2), often reflecting different mutations (evi 3 + c3). As a result, tumour types that cannot be distinguished pathologically, (evi 4 + c4) but that can be distinguished on the basis of differences in gene-expression profile (evi 5 + c5), can be examined for differences in treatment sensitivity (epi 3) … Gene-expression profiling of cancer stem cells would allow the profile to reflect the biology of the cells that are actually driving tumorigenesis (epi 4 + c 6). Microdissection of morphologically homogeneous collections of cancer cells is one way of generating profiles that reflect more homogeneous collections of cells (epi 5). The next frontier will be to purify the cancer stem cells from the whole tumour (epi 6) that retain unlimited proliferative potential (evi 6) and to perform gene-expression profiling on these cells (epi 7). In addition to being a more efficient way of identifying new therapeutic and diagnostic targets, the profiling of cancer stem cells might sharpen the differences in patterns observed between different tumours.” (Reya et al. 2001, 110)

Fragment 2 (Jain 2005, 58) surveys “solid tumour” morphology and the vascular efficacy of cancerous growths. Article 2 asserts, in so doing, that the veracity of tumours may be reduced through vascular therapeutics—a departure from the conventional wisdom which has long since maintained “That certain antiangiogenic agents can also transiently “normalize” the abnormal structure and function of tumor (sic.) vasculature to make it more efficient for oxygen and drug delivery.” Jain contends that the established practice of attacking tumours and damaging their vascular architecture may have a regressive impact upon drug treatment. The morphology (physical form) and vascular etiology (functioning) of cancers are depicted in tandem with knowledge of the effects that conventional drug related interventions have upon the configuration of their blood and oxygen delivery systems (Jain 2005, 58-9). A historiography is related in which the conventional wisdom—that tumours should be starved of vital blood and oxygen resources by “inhibiting vessel formation”—is contrasted with new hypotheses suggesting that the delivery of chemotherapy is more effective in tumours with healthy vascular systems.

Fragment 2 begins with a description of tumour vascular morbidity arising from conventional drug therapies. In so doing, it follows a similar ontological precept to that which may be found in Reya et al, with the notable exception that Jain makes more of the attendant “negatives” inherent to the science. Notwithstanding, Jain approaches these hazards utilising words such as “destroy” “damaging,” “interfering”, “render,” and “antagonize,” signaling that these hazards are being dealt with assertively. There is an implied positivity attached to Jain’s symbolic depiction of cancer scientists’ fortitude and their unswerving resolve to dispatch an unpredictable foe. Jain achieves this perspicacious representational effect by firstly pairing modals that depict positives and certainties. He then switches, when necessary, to modals that positively adduce the chances of resolving fissures, negatives and uncertainties in the science base. Jain uses a blend of evidence-led and epistemically-led modalities to separate “positive positives” from “negative positives”. Jain’s prose leaves a strong impression of demonstrative phronesis and an effusive potential for new discoveries:
Paragraph 2: “These clinical data support the earlier predictions of Teicher, who postulated that combined administration of antiangiogenic and cytotoxic (chemo- and radiation) therapies would yield maximal benefit because such combinations would destroy two separate compartments of tumors—cancer cells and endothelial cells (evi 1 + c 1 + epi 2 + evi 2). Cytotoxic agents would kill cancer cells directly (epi 3 + evi 3 + c 2), and data suggest that chemotherapy and radiation therapy may also have antiangiogenic effects (evi 4 + c 3), directly damaging or killing tumor endothelia cells (evi 5 + c 4), and thus enhancing the indirect killing of cancer cells (evi 6 + c 5). Furthermore, cancer cells may express receptors for angiogenic growth factors (e.g. VEGFR1 oe VEGFR2) (epi 4) and thus antiangiogenic drugs (e.g. antibody to VEGF) could lead to the direct killing of cancer cells by interfering with survival pathways and / or enhancing sensitivity to other treatments (epi 6). All of these mechanisms imply that an antiangiogenic agent would always augment the response to radiation or chemotherapy (epi 6 + c 6)”. (Jain 2005, 58)
Paragraph 15: “Perhaps the reason why only 15% of mice progress to AML in mice expressing Bcl-2 and lacking Fas is that the progenitors in these mice also must acquire an additional mutation that causes dysregulated self-renewal (epi 1 + evi 1 + c 1 + epi 2). If a single additional mutation causes transformation (epi 3) then this transforming event is probably a gain-of-function mutation (epi 4 + c 2), such as one that promotes constitutive self-renewal (epi 5). Because stabilized B-catenin can promote the self-renewal of HSCs (evi 2), and other types of progenitors (ref. 25 and T.R. et al. submitted) we propose that gain-of-function mutations in B-catenin may in many cases, transform deathless pre-malignant cells into cancer cells by promoting proliferation (epi 6 + ev 3). In support of this is evidence to show that activation of B-catenin and dysregulation of the Wnt signalling pathway in general is common in cancer (evi 3 + c 3) and that the targeted overactivation of the pathway can lead to tumours in transgenic mice (evi 3 + c 3). It is also possible that mutations in other signalling pathways promote progenitor self-renewal (epi 6). It is important to study this further, because understanding the molecular basis of the unregulated self-renewal of cancer cells will allow the design of more effective therapies (epi 7). (Reya et al. 2001, 108)
Paragraph 19: “An alternative approach is to develop agents that mimic such antiangiogenic cocktails by targeting upstream pathways that regulate the production of angiogenic molecules (epi 1). Such drugs already exist and have been approved by the FDA (evi 1 + c 2). For example, one recent study has shown that an antibody to HER2, trastuzumab (also known as Herceptin), acts on multiple angiogenic pathways in HER2-overexpressing human breast cancer xenografts (evi 2 + c 2). Herceptin lowers the expression of several proangiogenic molecules while increasing expression of the antiangiogenic molecule thrombospondin-1 (evi 3 + c 3). Interestingly, although Herceptin lowered the expression of VEGF in tumor cells (evi 4 + c4), the host cells within the tumor stroma produced compensatory VEGF (evi 5 + c5); thus, additional anti-VEGF treatment could improve the efficacy of Herceptin (epi 2). On the basis of these preclinical results, a clinical trial has been initiated in which Herceptin is combined with bevacizumab for treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer” (evi 6+ c6). (Jain 2005, 61)
Paragraph 29: “At least three major challenges must be met before therapies based on this vascular normalization model can be successfully translated to the clinic (epi 1). The first challenge is to determine which other direct or indirect antiangiogenic therapies lead to vascular normalization (epi 1+ uc 1) … Recently, metronomic therapy—a drug delivery method in which low doses of chemotherapeutic agents are given at frequent intervals- has also been shown to increase expression of thrombospondin-1 (evi 2 + c 1), which is a potent endogenous angiogenesis inhibitor (evi 3 + c 2) … To date, most clinical trials are designed primarily to measure changes in the size of the tumor and may therefore not shed light on changes in the vascular biology of tumors (epi 2). Clinical studies, such as the rectal carcinoma study described earlier, and other ongoing translational clinical trials should help bridge the gaps in this aspect of our knowledge”(epi 3)”. (Jain 2005, 62)

Fragment 3 is taken from Tomasek et al. (2002, 349). It primarily examines stem cell pluripotency in relation to “the modulation of fibroblastic cells,” which is described as “enigmatic” in its etiology or cell behavior “not least owing to its transient appearance in association with connective-tissue injury.” Tomasek et al. begin by locating the research within existing knowledge of this cell type. The notion of enigma is center-stage within their opening assertions. As they augment this storyline, Tomasek et al. strongly emphasize what has been observed of “connective tissue” performance in the past; particularly its mechanical dexterity, coupled with an ability to exert “tension even at rest” or stimulate “wound contraction.” Renewing “connective tension” in cases of tissue damage is revealed as a primary concern of the discipline (Tomasek et al. 2002, 349). The text then becomes focused on the contingencies of myofibroblasts—the complications they give rise to; their place in the mechanical “engineering” schema of skin, bones, cartilage, and muscle; the undisputable “laws” in which these bodily systems are couched (Tomasek et al. 2002, 350); as well as the hypotheses and observations generated by previous studies and knowledge of the differences between “myofibroblasts” and “fibroblasts.” The narrative continues with a detailed biographic profile of the myofibroblastic cell—augmenting a vivid representation of its characteristics and “behavioral profile.” Writing in a similar stance to Jain, Tomasek et al., emphasize the uncertainties inherent to the study of fibroblasts and “gap junctions” (Tomasek et al. 2002, 351). Evidential modalities are used to support an evaluative mode of storytelling in Fragment 3. The topics of cellular tension, contracting in wound healing, and malfunctions in burns cases are addressed in the latter half of the article, where a positively accentuated discussion of knowledge gray areas takes place. A phronetic depiction of these knowledge puzzles ensues, as illustrated by the following passages of text:
Paragraph 4: “The notion that granulation tissue contraction depends on force that is generated in this is very old. The traditional view has been that the mechanism of contraction was mainly due to collagen shortening (epi 1 + c 1). However, several observations had indicated that granulation-tissue cells could be important for force generation (epi 2 + evi 1 + c 2). Modified fibroblasts with smooth-muscle (SM)-like features (myofibroblasts) were first observed in granulation tissue of healing wounds (evi 2 + c 3), which led to the suggestion that these cells have a role in the production of the contractile force that is involved in this process (epi 3 + c 4). The presence of myofibroblasts in most fibro-contractive diseases (for example Dupuytren’s disease) and even in developing and specialized normal tissues (for example, lung septa) has extended this possibility to several situations (epi 4 + evi 3). It has subsequently been shown that most myfibroblasts express X-SM-actin (the actin isoform typically found in vascular SM cells) and that the expression of X-SM-actin and collagen type-I in these cells is co-ordinately regulated by transforming growth factor B1 (TGF-B1) (evi 4 + c 5). All these observations indicate that the myofibroblasts has a role in the synthesis of ECM and in force generation (evi 5 + c6), which results in ECM reorganization and wound contraction (evi 6 + c 7)”. (Tomasek et al. 2002, 350)
Paragraph 7: “Although myofibroblasts are clearly present in granulation tissue during wound closure and in pathological contracture tissues, questions have arisen as to whether they are essential for collagen / granulation tissue contraction (evi 1 + c1 + epi 1 + u 1). It is clear that tractional forces that are generated by fibroblasts as they migrate on a compliant substratum can reorganize collagen matrices (evi 2 + c2). In fact, in free floating collagen lattices the resulting reduction in lattice diameter is due entirely to fibroblast tractional forces (evi 3 + c 3). It has been proposed that tractional forces generated by fibroblasts migrating into granulation tissue are sufficient to result in wound closure (epi 2 + evi 4 + c 4), which makes the involvement of a specialized contractile cell unnecessary (epi 3). Although tractional forces that are generated by fibroblasts might be sufficient to initiate wound closure (epi 4 + evi 5 + c 5), the subsequent appearance of resistance in the surrounding tissue induces the DIFFERENTIATION of myofibroblasts (evi 6 + c 6), and only then can contraction be considered to start (evi 7 + c 7). Other studies have questioned whether granulation tissue, and thereby myofibroblasts, are even necessary for wound closure in animals that have relatively immobile skin, such as pigs and humans (epi 5 + uc 2) . The ability of some models of immobile skin to contract without granulation tissue might reflect traction and contraction processes that can compensate for each other (epi 6). It now seems likely that both traction and contraction are important at different stages in wound healing (discussed below), and questions now should focus on the detailed mechanisms (epi 7)”. (Tomasek et al. 2002, 351)
Paragraph 32: “So, how is the contractile force that is generated by myofibroblasts translated into a shortened collagen matrix that no longer requires active cell contraction to maintain a tissue tension (epi 1+ u 1)? So far the mechanism for this has been ascribed simply to collagen cross-linking (evi 1 + c 1), but the permanency of this covalent bonding is irreconcilable with the dynamic nature of the process (evi2 + u 2). Matrix shortening and increased stiffness indicates that the resident cells have locked a tension into the collagen structure, but in an interstitial, incremental manner (evi 3 + c 2). This represents a ‘slip and ratchet’ theory for contracture, but it can only realistically occur as a localized, dynamic and incremental process that is not consistent with massive breakdown, re-assembly and cross-linking (evi 4 + u 3). Related concepts in which collagen fibrils slip past one another locally and are then re-linked whereas adjacent fibrils are, in their turn, unbonded and slipped have been proposed (epi 2 + u 4). It is noteworthy that in granulation tissue of a normal healing wound or in fibrocontractive diseases, collagen type I is replaced to a great extent by collagen type III (evi 5 + c 3), which is known to be present in remodelling tissues (for example during development) or in normal tissues that are subject to mechanical stress (for example arteries) (evi 6 + c 4)”. (Tomasek et al. 2002, 358)

sec.title: Key Observations of the Data
sec.p: Fragments 1-3 are shown here as illustrations of the rhetorical practices framed in Articles 1-3. They are indicative, rather than exhaustive, drawing attention to the ontological nature of modal splicing practices, which tend (as predicted by Star 1985) to “organize” and “sort” their largely taxonomical subject matter into categorizations that prioritize evidentiality over theory; and confident/certain observations over those of ambiguous, indeterminate, conjectural, and hypothetical provenance (see also Hyland 1998; Mushin 2001). These sorting and splicing practices underwrite the positive rhetorical accentuation of discoveries in Articles 1-3. By so doing, they initiate the inscription of (phronetic) representational effects, emphasizing virtue, worthwhileness, perspicacity, and fortitude. These representations, among others, are cemented on the “bricks and mortar” of single modal ascriptions (for instance, one per sentence) and didactic modal pairings that splice knowledge into two-, three-, and four-sided frames (Tannen 1993).

Within the fragments considered, when two or more modalities align to create two-sided frames, they often do so using a pairing arrangement of “evidentiality + certainty”. This particular form of modal didacticism is an important conveyer for the communication of “positive signifiers,” which help amass confidence in the science at hand among readerships, while also forging impressions of taxonomical efficacy and legitimacy. Single and didactic (or two-sided) modal frames were expanded in each fragment, when the authors so required. Notably, these extra splices served to either explore ambivalences in greater depth or justify a taxonomical adducement. In both instances, this “search” was performed in the hope of finding something reassuring, concrete or verisimilitudinal in an otherwise confusing picture. When expedited, this practice most often leveraged triple or quadruple polydidactic forms of modal placement (or three- and four-side frames).

Single, didactic and polydidactic forms of modal splicing categorize knowledge differently. As might be expected, single and didactic splicing “sorts out” easily delineable types of knowledge, yielding a representation effect of clarity, sharp separation, and limpid observation. By itself this is an exceptionally important lever for perspicacious impression building within “virtue prose.” Thus, it may be conjectured that the simpler the splice, the more perspicacious, morally intense, confident and clear-sighted the scientist appears to be. More complex polydidactic modal placements seem to be instantiated where certain and uncertain attributions cannot be as easily delineated and separated. In these more ambivalent circumstances, polydidactic modal splicing played a reassuring role, helping to identify positive signals, even if they are in trace form. Longer polydidactic expurgations were seemingly also conjectured when scientists needed to affirm a positive assertion. In both senses, polydidactic modal splicing was a significant source of confidence building and sense-rendering of worthwhileness, mooted in Articles 1-3.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: Articles 1-3, use the modal “literary technology” (Myers 1992) described above to textually endow upbeat renditions of phronetic virtue in which physical, technical, cognitive, and conceptual resources are combined to “overcome” the ambivalent proclivities of stem cells. The first purpose of modal splicing and switching is to sort, sift, and ontologically frame these ambivalences by separating them from far less discordant knowledge certainties, about which positive things can be said. Their second purpose is to create “tropes”—or thematically linked impressions—that are illustrative of virtuous scientific conduct, creating images of diligent, unbiased, neutral, morally apt, demonstrative, perspicacious, and incisive detective work (see for instance, Star 1985).

Successful image making of “perspicacious phronesis” is perhaps the most subliminal means scientists have at their disposal to demonstrate efficacy and compliance. This is especially true among subscribers to the “standard model” scientific rule book (Rosa 1998). As the “orthodox paradigm” in science, standard model realism is believed to have spent much of its history cultivating a mode of truth-telling that asserts moral rectitude by first appealing to transparency of conduct, then to verbal thrift and epistemological temperance. Standard model positivism of the type emulated by stem cell scientists draws upon perspicacity as an important source for this legitimation (Star 1985, 1989). Story aids perspicacious representation by binding all other available syntactic resources into a sequentially staged narrative of virtue that follows a classical Labovian form (Patterson 2008). This article suggests, moreover, that perspicacious tropes primarily perform visual roles (Gooding 2009), conjuring images of thoroughness and authenticity that court the reader into believing that they are interacting with entirely translucent and truthful textual accounts of scientific phronesis, conducted to advance the betterment of humanity. Once agreed, this “bargain” between reader and scientists-as-author facilitates the presentation of positive-leaning rhetoric that shows the glass as half full.

While limited to three fragments, the research to which this article relates suggests that positive positivism may be an important “mother tongue” of the stem cell laboratory that has helped scientists to legitimize their work among peer review audiences (Myers 1992; Hyland 1998; Mushin 2001). STS theorists have shown consistently that modern science publishing seems to favor aesthetically and semantically confident versions of laboratory stories that emphasize solidity, certainty, and positivity, preferring wars won to battles lost (Knorr-Cetina 1981; Pinch 1981; Star 1985, 1989; Mellor 2010; Gross, Harmon, and Reidy 2002; Gross 2006). In agreement with these theorists, I find that to become a published scientific author, social actants must acquire the literary skills needed to satisfy this requirement. Most often these skills develop experientially, over the course of a career in scientific publishing. As a result, the successful scientific author may be unaware of the extent to which they have become literate in rhetoric of positivity that attests Aristotelian notions of “prudence”. Past STS inquiry has shown that this literacy becomes especially significant during the preparation of manuscripts for peer review and eventual publication, when demonstrations of “uncertainty taming,” positively instantiated positivism, perspicacity, virtue, valor, and fortitude, become associated with (moral) scientific authority, rigor, and due diligence.
